sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: This is your news tonight, the headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Thumbs up from the European Commission.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Ukraine should be given EU candidate status, Ursula von der Leyen says, adding that it's now in Kiev's hands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: President Vladimir Putin speaks at the Economic Forum in St. Petersburg, calling Western sanctions reckless and insane and defending the Russian aggression in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The UK government signs off on the extradition of Julian Assange to the US where he's facing espionage charges but the WikiLeaks team is refusing to give up saying it's the beginning of a new legal battle. And are the recent fires at food processing plants in the US really an attempt to create a national food crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We'll take a closer look here in The Cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Good evening. Welcome to the program.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: I'm Per Berg for Snyberg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The European Commission has recommended candidate status for Ukraine in a symbolic show of support in the war-torn country's quest to join the bloc.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Sporting a yellow and blue outfit, EU chief Ursula von der Leyen told officials on Friday that Ukraine and neighboring Moldova should be welcomed as candidate countries. The move could kick-start a lengthy process towards full EU membership, which could take years. It comes just a day after top EU leaders offered their backing to Ukraine's EU accession during a trip to its capital. Member states will decide next week whether to grant the country's candidate status with unanimous agreement required.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Foreign alliance says that Ukraine has already proved its European worth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In the view of the Commission, Ukraine has clearly demonstrated the country's aspiration and the country's determination to live up to European values and standards. And we all know that Ukrainians are ready to die for the European perspective. We want them to live with us the european dream now let's head to brussels

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: i'm bringing in our correspondent maeve mcmahon and maeve so some strong words there from ursula von der leyen saying now that she wants the ukrainians to live the european dream what's been the reaction there in brussels well as you can imagine among ukrainians who are based here in Brussels, the reaction has been very positive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I'm standing here now with Anna, Martha and Oksana, ladies that I've met since the Russian invasion back on the 24th of February, ladies who've been organizing the demonstrations here, the pro-Ukrainian demonstrations and anti-Russia demonstrations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So let's bring them in and get their initial reaction to that announcement today from the European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I guess that this is a huge morale boost.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Are you afraid that the EU won't follow through, Anna?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Indeed, we are very happy. We believe it's a historic decision for Ukraine because today Ukraine is fighting not only for its independence and freedom, but also for our European future, for the European values. And getting the candidacy status would be a huge boost in morale for Ukraine. And Martha, what are people saying back home, your friends and family back in Ukraine? People are, of course, fighting for European values. They expect to have the candidacy status. They do not even have a slight doubt that we will get it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Of course, they ask us. They all the time are in contact with us asking what is now decision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Is there anything changing? We are preparing ourselves for different demonstrations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Like there was a human chain back a few days ago near the Berlemont building, like here, 1,000 people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And there are other demonstrations that we are making just to raise awareness and to let the leaders hear that civil society is expecting that we will be part of European family one day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And this is the first step.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is the first step. Oksana, are you confident that EU member states will give it the green light next week?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We do our best to support this positive decision for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We do a really lot of work with all of the permanent representatives here in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We try to lobby the best interests for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So we are doing our best for our people back there in Ukraine, in occupied territories, so they know that we keep fighting for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Okay. Anna, Martha and Oksana, thank you so much. Really interesting to hear the perspective there from Ukrainians based here in Brussels, putting pressure on the European institutions since that invasion and even since 2014, actually, since the Maidan revolution.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, Maeve, some happy voices there behind you. But, of course, this process of becoming an actual member of the EU can be quite a long one for Albania.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: It took five years to get candidate status.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: North Macedonia, that country has been a candidate since 2005 and is still waiting to open membership talks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: How fast is it going to go for Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, it's not going to be a fast process at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's not just going to happen overnight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In fact, negotiations on the reforms won't even start.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The official accession talks won't even start, even if this candidate status is granted at that EU summit next week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That's why we heard today from Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, saying the process will be very fluid. There will be bumps. It could go forward. It could go backwards. And as you say, it could take a long time, as we've seen with other countries who are trying to get inside the bloc. And what happens is once this procedure is formalized, then this chapter, which is called the Copenhagen criteria, which consists of 35 different chapters, tricky difficult chapters on all areas of EU reform and law need to be dealt with and need to be signed off upon and then you need to get the green light on an accession treaty from not just the EU member states but then from Ukraine itself. So these girls behind me they are in their late 20s early 30s and believe that it could be they could be into their 50s before they officially see themselves as a member of the EU with their president sitting around that council table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: All right, long journey ahead. Thank you so much, May McClellan, live for us in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And following the visit by EU leaders on Thursday, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: made a surprise trip to Kiev for talks with Ukraine's President Zelensky.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: It's Johnson's second outing to the country since the war broke out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Zelensky welcomed the PM's visit, saying Great Britain's support for Ukraine is firm and resolute.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Elsewhere in Ukraine, at least two people have been killed and many more injured in a Russian missile strike in the southern city of Mykolaiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: According to the city's governor, four residential buildings were destroyed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: French network operator GRT Gas announced today that they hadn't received any Russian gas for the last two days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The announcement comes as Gazprom, Russia's state energy company, said it was cutting supplies to Germany by 40 percent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Similarly, Italian energy giant Eni said that Gazprom would reduce supplies by 50 percent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said reductions in supply were not premeditated, but related to maintenance issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: However, the head of Gazprom puts the blame on the West, saying, Our product, our rules. issues however the head of Gazprom puts the blame on the West saying our product our rules meanwhile Russian President Vladimir Putin has denounced the West for attempting to impose its will on sovereign nations speaking at the Saint Petersburg International Economic Forum Putin declared that the world has fundamentally changed and that the era of unipolar world is over.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The United States, having declared victory in the Cold War, declared itself the messenger of God on Earth, who has no responsibilities, but only interests, and those interests are declared sacred.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: and those interests are declared sacred.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They do not seem to notice that over the past decades, new powerful centres have been formed on the planet and are declaring themselves louder and louder.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Each of them develops its own political systems and public institutions, implements its own models of economic growth and, of course, has the right to protect them to ensure national sovereignty.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: economic growth and of course has the right to protect them to ensure national sovereignty and our correspondent galena polonska joins me now live galena what did vladimir putin have to say now that the eu is further opening the door for ukraine on its path towards eu membership

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: hello well vladimir putin said that the eu is not a military political bloc, unlike NATO, and that Russia has nothing against such a perspective opening for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He said that it was a sovereign decision of the EU to decide whether it wants this country, Ukraine, this country, Ukraine, to join this economic alliance and said that Russia has no objections against such a decision. He also said that if this happens, the EU would most probably provide financial support for the daily life in Ukraine, but said that he doubts that it would help to restore its critical infrastructures as he doubts that the you could create competitors but we're putting also spoke about the future of the EU in itself and said that he is persuaded that it will face a change of the elites in the future as people right now are suffering from sanctions in the EU from sanctions imposed on Russia and he said that populist mood will rise surely and also he said that the EU has lost its political sovereignty and Galena he also defended his decision to invade Ukraine or as he puts it, this special military operation in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But was there any kind of recognition of the immense human cost, those thousands of civilians who've now died in this war?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Not a single word pair. Vladimir Putin, however, said that fighting is always a tragedy, but repeated once again that Russia did not have a choice, that it was dragged to this line, and promised once again that Russia will attain its goals in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: in Ukraine. And those words were met with massive applause in the whole of the Economic Forum in St. Petersburg. Vladimir Putin was also asked about the danger of the beginning of the Third World War. And he said that this rhetoric comes from the Western leaders, that Russia just responds to their comments and that there is no threat coming from Russia. However, he stressed that everyone knows what Russia disposes, what means Russia disposes and what would be its answer in case of a danger. There was also another very interesting question about Russia's warnings to attack the decision-making centers in Ukraine. Vladimir Putin said that he did not want to give details and said that this would mean very tough actions from the Russian side, but he stressed that it is up to Ukraine and the West to draw their own conclusions with what they may collide if they cross the red lines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Kalina Polonskaya, live for us. Thank you so much Kalina.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Britain has given the green light to extradite Julian Assange to the US where he will face trial over the publication of secret military files.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The move could bring the WikiLeaks founders long running legal saga closer to a conclusion and comes after a

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: UK court issued a formal order clearing Assange removal in April he's wanted by US authorities on 18 counts including a spying charge his supporters have decried the decision claiming it's a violation of media freedom and free speech now let's head to London and speak to our reporter Vincent McAvini who joins us now live from London. Vincent, so why did the UK government approve this extradition now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well Julian Assange's presence in the United Kingdom has been a problem for British governments over 10 years now. He has worked his way through the British legal system. He was first wanted in connection with a case in Sweden that was subsequently dropped, but he breached bail conditions here in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He then fled inside the Ecuadorian embassy and stayed there for a number of years until eventually the Ecuadorians decided they'd had enough of him and gave him up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He was then arrested by Britain, and he spent the last couple of years in Belmarsh Prison in South London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And whilst he was in a custodial sentence for that breach of bail conditions, these charges from the US came in. Now, Britain has not wanted Julian Assange in this country, essentially. It's also a bit of a mistake for them with the Americans. The UK is obviously very closely aligned. We were also part of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and both countries were embarrassed by the revelations that came out in those leaks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And so Britain has, over the past two years, sought reassurances from the U.S. It has a treaty where it can extract people, but it has to have the reassurance that the person will not face any kind of torture and will not face a capital sentence, the death punishment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Then they can be extradited. So Julian Assange was given a full and fair legal proceeding here in the UK. He went all the way up to the Supreme Court. He lost his case repeatedly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And he is now on the decision of the Home Secretary, Priti Patel, going to America, because she has had the reassurances of that key condition, that he will not face the death penalty. And so she is within her right now under British law to send him to America.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So is this it? Is he going on a plane to the US now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well Julian Assange has 14 days to appeal. He could appeal to the ECHR, the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg but a decade ago in another case that court found that it was all right for Britain to extradite people under its treaty agreements with the United States. It was a case on different facts. It might get reviewed differently now but there is precedent for it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So essentially Julian Assange has run down the clock now in the UK and at any point essentially within the next 14 days it does seem he could be put on a flight and flown to the US if that's what the Home Secretary decides is the right course of action. Vincent McAvaney live for us from London. Thank you Vincent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now recent fires across the United States at food processing plants has

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: sparked numerous conspiracy theories that someone that might actually be starting them intentionally to create a national food shortage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Sophia in the Cube has more on this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Sophia?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Yes, Per.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We've been seeing these sorts of posts circulating all over social media.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In it they claim that there has been an increase in fires at food processing plants in the U.S. in order to starve the population.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Now even politicians are getting involved such as Marjorie Taylor Greene that insinuated on Twitter that maybe these incidents were not that accidental. And even on Facebook we've been seeing these sorts of posts that suggest that maybe even Bill Gates is behind all of this. So here at the Cube we decided to fact-check these claims and we found no evidence that any of these fires were premeditated in order to cause some sort of national food shortage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And as you can see, most of these fires, like this one in Maine, were accidental.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Only three fires are still currently undergoing investigation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But has there really been an alarming increase?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Let's take a look at the numbers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Let's start with this report from 2019 by the USDA.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: That's the United States Department of Agriculture.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In it, it says that the U.S. has over 36,000 food processing plants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And according to the National Fire Protection Association, so that's the NFPA, the annual average amount of fires between 2015 and 2019 in food processing plants was over 5,000.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So as you can see, it is quite a common occurrence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And in the first four months of 2022, there have been approximately 20 fires at food plants, according to an NFPA spokesperson who gave an interview to factcheck.org.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So as you can see, these numbers are not really that alarmingly high. And also, most of these plans were only temporarily shut down. So this wouldn't cause some sort of national food crisis. And there, the USDA even said on its website that there are currently no food shortages or disruptions in the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: All right, Sophia in the cube. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: or disruptions in the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: All right, Sofia in the Cube, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The European Broadcasting Union has announced that Ukraine cannot host Eurovision next year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The show's organizers say next year's events won't go ahead in the winning country because of Russia's ongoing war, but it could be held in the runner-up nation, the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The BBC is now in talks with the European Broadcasting Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But reports say Ukraine's culture minister is demanding further talks on the matter, posting to Telegram that the country is still prepared to host the event.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The Japanese Supreme Court has ruled that the government is absolved of any and all responsibility

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: for the Fukushima nuclear disaster. In 2011, a tsunami triggered by an earthquake hit the power plant, creating the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl. Today's ruling means that the operator of the plant, the Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings, is liable for close to 10 million euros in compensation for up to 3,700 plaintiffs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And FIFA has announced the host cities for the 2026 World Cup Cups following its central role in the 1970 and the 1986 finals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Other selected cities include Los Angeles, Dallas and Philadelphia, while Vancouver and Toronto will be the venues as Canada hosts its first ever men's World Cup finals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Forecasters have warned that temperatures are set to

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: hit 40 degrees Celsius in parts of Europe this weekend as a heat wave has people across the continent trying to escape the Sun. Anca Ulla has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Scorching heat has sent Europeans across the continent scrambling for shade and water as an unusually early heat wave spread across several countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Temperatures blew past historical records for this time of the year, hitting over 40 degrees Celsius in some places.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're barely bearing the heat.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It's terrible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I drink a lot of water.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We go back to the apartment and switch on the air conditioning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The heat wave is said to continue to spread over the weekend, with temperatures higher than 30 degrees Celsius expected in most of Western and Central Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Meteorologists say these temperatures are normally recorded in July and August.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: French climate scientists say this is the earliest heat wave France has seen since 1947, saying it's a direct consequence of climate change. And swimming pools are in high demand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: There are between 800 and 1,000 people per day. It's huge compared to the usual days when there are few clouds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The heat could even be deadly, especially for elderly people who are particularly vulnerable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: France has activated its highest alert level in more than a dozen regions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Across Europe, hydration is key.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is the second water bottle in half an hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It's very hot, so, as you say on TV, we must drink a lot of water.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For older people, it's quite hard.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In northern Italy, the extreme heat is adding to a severe drought.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Some parts of the Po River, the country's largest, have run dry.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Anca Ulla, Euronews.
